author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Excellence Runs in the Family. Her Novel’s Heroine Wants Something Else.
description: Kaitlyn Greenidge and her sisters achieved success in their respective fields. In her historical novel, “Libertie,” she focuses on a Black woman who doesn’t yearn to be the first or only one of anything.
content: Libertie, the rebellious heroine of Kaitlyn Greenidge’s new novel, comes from an extraordinary family, but longs to be ordinary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Gabrielle Hamilton has a delightful new recipe for a peanut-butter wafer cake that’s worth your time absolutely.
content: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton quit drinking for the month of January and watched her consumption of sugar soar: supermarket cakes; pints of ice cream; lots and lots of Little Debbie Nutty Buddy bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Nawal El Saadawi, Advocate for Women in the Arab World, Dies at 89
description: An author, physician and champion of equal rights, she was jailed by Anwar Sadat for her activism against the Egyptian government.
content: Nawal el Saadawi, an Egyptian author, activist and physician who became an emblem of the struggle for women’s rights in the patriarchal Arab world and campaigned against female genital mutilation, which she had endured at age 6, died on Sunday in Cairo. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: New York reports its first case of the troubling variant that is dominant in Brazil.
description: Health officials worry that variants will become the dominant source of infection soon as thousands of cases continue to be reported for other variants found in Britain, South Africa and Brazil.
content: New York has joined a growing list of more than a dozen states that have confirmed at least one case of a worrisome coronavirus variant first found in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Snyder Cut: What’s New, What’s Gone (and More About That Ending)
description: Here’s a guide to just how different “Zack Snyder’s Justice League” is from the version Joss Whedon finished in 2017.
content: “Zack Snyder’s Justice League,” out now on HBO Max, bears very little resemblance to the version of “Justice League” released by Warner Bros. in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Petting a Horse, Looking for Bliss
description: After learning about a program in New Mexico favored by some celebrities and companies, a Times reporter just had to try it for herself.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Stephanie Saul
title: Why Some Georgia Lawmakers Want Last Week’s Shootings Labeled Hate Crimes
description: Violence that left eight dead, including six women of Asian descent, will be the first stress test for a Georgia hate crime law.
content: A year ago, Georgia was one of four states that had no hate crime legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: In Kabul’s Streets, Dogs Rule the Night
description: Almost every city in the world has to deal with street crime, and some with dog packs. But few, if any, have to navigate such an underworld while also confronting unrelenting war.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Civilians in Afghanistan’s capital live in constant fear of being killed in a targeted attack as the war with the Taliban and other extremist groups drags on. But at night, a different war is being fought — against criminals, and packs of stray dogs stalking the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Always an Afterthought’: Schools Are Closed, but Not Child Care Centers
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 21, 2021.
content: “We treat public education as the public good that it is, but we don’t do that for child care. We’ve created this false dichotomy between the two.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: The Loyola-Chicago Ramblers, and Sister Jean, Return to the Round of 16
description: The Ramblers, who went to the Final Four in 2018, knocked off No. 1-seeded Illinois, the latest upset in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, which has been rife with them.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Over the last year, there has been a greater appreciation for so many of life’s routine pleasures, particularly communal experiences — dinner with friends, a night at the movies, a day at the ballpark, holidays with family. For Cameron Krutwig, and so many other college basketball players, it was for an elemental joy that they have treasured more than ever: the bounce of a ball on hardwood and the sweat equity built only through competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: After Sarah Everard’s Killing, Women’s Groups Want Change, Not More Policing
description: A rising movement in Britain asserts that the police are part of the problem and seeks recognition that violence against women must be addressed at the societal level.
content: Late Thursday night, Sisters Uncut, a provocative feminist organization that has emerged as a leader of the most forceful protests in Britain’s growing national movement around women’s safety, declared a small victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: No March Madness? For Those Headed to the N.B.A., That’s Just Fine.
description: The N.C.A.A. basketball tournament has sometimes been a great showcase for future N.B.A. talent, but history suggests that the biggest stage of college hoops isn’t a make-or-break deal for the pros.
content: Markelle Fultz did not need March Madness. Neither did Luka Doncic, Ben Simmons and plenty of other basketball stars going back decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: India Battles a Second Covid-19 Wave and Vaccine Skepticism
description: An outbreak around Mumbai has led to a campaign for more inoculations. That could affect supplies around the world.
content: MUMBAI — India is racing to contain a second wave of the coronavirus, but its vaccination campaign is running into doubters like Akbar Mohamed Patel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Evidence in Capitol Attack Most Likely Supports Sedition Charges, Prosecutor Says
description: “I personally believe the evidence is trending toward that, and probably meets those elements,” said Michael Sherwin, who had led the Justice Department’s inquiry into the riot.
content: WASHINGTON — Evidence the government obtained in the investigation into the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol most likely meets the bar necessary to charge some of the suspects with sedition, Michael R. Sherwin, the federal prosecutor who had been leading the Justice Department’s inquiry, said in an interview that aired on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Tour a Tenement and Celebrate Passover
description: This week, stream a French film, watch a ballet performance and learn about restoring Earth’s oceans.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The U.S. defense secretary’s visit to Afghanistan.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin landed in Kabul on Sunday morning, becoming the first member of President Biden’s cabinet to set foot in the country, which is home to America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: He Redefined ‘Racist.’ Now He’s Trying to Build a Newsroom.
description: The author Ibram Kendi and The Boston Globe team up to cover racism, inspired by Boston’s 19th century abolitionist newspapers.
content: BOSTON — Ibram X. Kendi and Bina Venkataraman met last summer when their big Boston institutions, Boston University and The Boston Globe, were grappling with protests over racial justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Gewirtz
title: Bracket pools vary in how they will handle the canceled game.
description: Depending on which contest you entered, you may or may not earn points as if Virginia Commonwealth and Oregon had played.
content: If you picked Oregon to win its first-round game in one of the popular online tournaments, you may or may not get points depending on which one you entered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
title: Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World
description: Despite warnings, American and European officials gave up leverage that could have guaranteed access for billions of people. That risks prolonging the pandemic.
content: In the coming days, a patent will finally be issued on a five-year-old invention, a feat of molecular engineering that is at the heart of at least five major Covid-19 vaccines. And the United States government will control that patent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Beauty of the Beasts’
description: How the beauty of animals is making scientists rethink evolution.
content: The bright elastic throats of anole lizards, the Fabergé abdomens of peacock spiders and the curling, iridescent and ludicrously long feathers of birds-of-paradise. A number of animal species possess beautifully conspicuous and physically burdensome features.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: March 21, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 21, 2021.
content: An essay on March 7 by the screenwriter and actress Emily Mortimer about “Lolita,” obscenity laws and cancel culture included several sentences adapted without attribution from an article by Caitlin Flanagan, “How ‘Lolita’ Seduces Us All,” that appeared in the September 2018 issue of The Atlantic. The online version of the essay has been revised to include attributions to Flanagan’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Keith Bradsher
title: Think Covid’s Messed Up Your Travel Plans? Try Getting Into China.
description: To keep the virus out, Beijing has enacted some of the world’s toughest border controls. Lives have been upended, and business has been disrupted.
content: Leave your partner and children behind. Quarantine for up to a month. Get inoculated with a Covid-19 vaccine from China, if you can find one. And prepare yourself for an anal swab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: Palestinians and Israelis Both Vote Soon. The Differences Are Stark.
description: Many Israelis feel numbed by their endless election cycle. Many Palestinians are excited about a rare chance to vote — but others expect little change without statehood.
content: JERUSALEM — When Yona Schnitzer, a 32-year-old Israeli content editor, heard about the latest Israeli election — Israel’s fourth in two years — he felt a surge of anger at how the government had collapsed yet again, and questioned the point of taking part. “My initial reaction was,” Mr. Schnitzer said, “‘I can’t believe this is happening again.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Kent Taylor, Texas Roadhouse Founder and C.E.O., Dies at 65
description: Mr. Taylor died by suicide after suffering from post-Covid-19 symptoms, including severe tinnitus, the company said.
content: Kent Taylor, the founder and chief executive of the Texas Roadhouse restaurant chain, died by suicide on Thursday after suffering from post-Covid-19 symptoms, the company and his family said in a statement. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: After Spa Attacks, Officers Handcuffed Victim’s Anguished Husband for Four Hours
description: In an interview with a Spanish-language news outlet, Mario González described his confusion and frustration as sheriff’s deputies detained him after the shooting.
content: ACWORTH, Ga. — Mario González heard the gunfire from inside Young’s Asian Massage and immediately worried about his wife, who was in another room. But before he could check on her, he said, law enforcement officials handcuffed and detained him for about four hours while they worked to determine the identity of the gunman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Julie Mehretu’s Reckoning With Success
description: Can you be both an agent of change and art-world royalty? This artist’s reign on the Whitney Museum’s fifth floor shows it’s possible.
content: In a moment when museum collections are trying to integrate more women and artists of color, Julie Mehretu represents a powerful symbol of progress, the rare example of a contemporary Black female painter who has already entered the canon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: The Private Lives of Strippers
description: In a new photo book, Chris Buck shares portraits and stories of strippers and their partners.
content: For his new photo book, “Gentlemen’s Club,” Chris Buck spent six years interviewing and taking portraits of strippers and their romantic partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Is It Hot in Here or Is It Me?
description: Daniel Grinberg dabbles in smoke and mirrors.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s tough to put together a perfectly balanced Monday puzzle. Ideally, it should be novel enough to engage the experienced solver who can breeze right through it, while providing enough rewards to keep newer puzzle fans working until they hear that jingle of success at the end. With today’s offering, Daniel Grinberg has managed to tick all the boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxanne Fequiere
title: Wander Through an Online Art Fair
description: Like every other industry, the art world is in a digital pivot right now. And people are logging on to creatively browse.
content: Whether you’re accustomed to building  your social calendar around must-see art fairs or are still confused why an event named after the Swiss city of Basel sets Miami alight each year, the past year saw a seismic shift for the art world’s aficionados and casual observers alike. With the rise of the online art fair, suddenly everyone had an opportunity to see some of the world’s most exciting art without leaving the couch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Recast as ‘Stimmies,’ Federal Relief Checks Drive a Stock Buying Spree
description: The government set out to prop up the economy. It may also be propping up the market.
content: Abraham Sanchez knew exactly how he wanted to spend his stimulus check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Aramco’s Profit Fell 44 Percent in 2020
description: But the giant oil company said it would pay $75 billion in dividends, nearly all of it to the Saudi government.
content: Saudi Aramco, Saudi Arabia’s national oil company, said on Sunday that its net income last year had fallen by 44 percent, to $49 billion, as lower oil prices stemming from the pandemic cut into earnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie G. Wong and Matt Craig
title: Workers at U.S. meat plants, early Covid hot spots, are now getting vaccinated in many states.
description: After the coronavirus spread rapidly last year in meatpacking facilities, food processing workers are now eligible for vaccines in at least 26 states, according to a New York Times survey.
content: Employees at food processing facilities, which had some of the country’s largest known coronavirus outbreaks early in the pandemic, are now eligible for vaccines in at least 26 states, a New York Times survey found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Hugh Newell Jacobsen, Famed Modernist Architect, Dies at 91
description: Mentored by Louis Kahn, he created designs for clients like Meryl Streep and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, as well as colleges and museums.
content: Hugh Newell Jacobsen, a Modernist architect who brought sophisticated designs to homes, most notably one belonging to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis on Martha’s Vineyard, as well as museums, universities and public buildings like the U.S. Capitol, died on March 4 in an assisted living facility in Front Royal, Va. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Live in one state and work in another? It can be tricky getting a vaccination.
description: A New Hampshire resident who teaches high school in Maine was denied shots by both states. She finally received her first shot at a health center in Maine.
content: Melanie Allen, a high school English teacher, was in a bind. She works in one state and lives in another. And both denied her a Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Reinfections are rare, some Covid ‘long haulers’ respond to vaccines: The week in coronavirus news.
description: New studies trying to better understand the coronavirus and its effects have come in this week.
content: New studies trying to better understand the coronavirus and its effects have come in this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniele Volpe and Kirk Semple
title: A Violent End to a Desperate Dream Leaves a Guatemalan Town Grieving
description: The trek from Central America to U.S. soil has always been perilous, but a massacre with many victims from one corner of Guatemala has shaken that country.
content: They leave behind homes, families, everything they have known, taking their chances on a dangerous trek north toward an uncertain future, driven by poverty, lack of opportunity and the hope of something better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Fully Vaccinated and Time to Party: If You Are 70
description: Older Americans still make up a majority of those who have been inoculated, and many are taking advantage and venturing out.
content: Bobby Stuckey flipped through receipts this month, surprised to see a huge increase in cocktail sales, the highest in the 17-year history of his restaurant, even though the bar section has been closed. The septuagenarians are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Nicholas Confessore
title: Access, Influence and Pardons: How a Set of Allies Shaped Trump’s Choices
description: A loose collection of well-connected groups and individuals led by a pair of Orthodox Jewish organizations had striking success in winning clemency for white-collar criminals during the Trump presidency.
content: WASHINGTON — One hacked the computers of business rivals. One bribed doctors to win referrals for his nursing homes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Wandered Off, a Man on a Bike Pulled Up Next to Me’
description: By the lake in Prospect Park, a parking space too good to leave and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Postal Service Struggles to Speed Up Delivery, Compounding Its Troubles
description: Months after the election highlighted the agency’s problems, delivery times are still falling short of its standards, and a plan to try to shore up its finances could further slow some mail.
content: WASHINGTON — William Pietri, a software engineer in San Francisco, put careful thought into his Christmas box for his family in Michigan, jamming it with tastes from around the world and other gifts: Indonesian ginger candy, Mexican saladitos con chile, Korean honey butter almonds, a puzzle that was almost impossible to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dore, Robert Vinluan and Logan Moseley
title: A Wander ‘Round the World
description: Use the clues left behind to follow in this traveler’s footsteps.
content: March 21 is the 80th day of 2021, and you’ve stumbled across a diary and a roughly drawn map of the itinerary of a mysterious traveler who seems to have journeyed around the world in that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Exploiting Black Fears of False Persecution
description: Politicians facing accusations seek to take advantage of Black support.
content: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has been engulfed in scandal, not only over allegations that his administration misstated and attempted to conceal data about Covid-19-related nursing home deaths, but also over a steady stream of allegations of sexual misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: The N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Is Overloaded With Talent
description: Freshman players like UConn’s Paige Bueckers, Iowa’s Caitlin Clark and Maryland’s Angel Reese help shine the spotlight on San Antonio.
content: This year’s women’s tournament boasts one of the strongest collections of basketball talent gathered in one place at one time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scenes of Mourning and Defiance
description: People gathered at memorials and rallies across the country to denounce the shootings in Atlanta and call for an end to anti-Asian violence.
content: At rallies and events in cities across the country, people gathered to grieve the killing of eight people, six of whom were women of Asian descent, in shootings that targeted three Atlanta-area massage businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Do British Uber Drivers Deserve Better Benefits?
description: Gig work doesn’t have to be a race to the bottom.
content: Some gig workers are more entitled to equality than others. That’s one takeaway from a ruling last month by the British Supreme Court, which found that contract Uber drivers must be classified as workers eligible for minimum pay and benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 22, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Patriots and 49ers Among N.F.L. Free Agency’s Biggest Spenders
description: The 2021 salary cap has put a crunch on some teams looking to shore up their rosters. Others have opened their wallets.
content: In an off-season characterized by a $182.5 million salary cap, down 8 percent from 2020, N.F.L. general managers are navigating the landscape carefully. With the official start of free agency underway, executives are looking at players to add — or keep — on their rosters, but only at the right price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Milk for Floors, Bread for Walls: 19th-Century Cleaning Tips for the Modern Era
description: Just in time for spring cleaning, a conservation group in England has delved into the past for how to clean in the present.
content: Want to live like a Bridgerton, the upper crust British family featured in the hit Netflix series? Promenading with handsome dukes and gossiping with a queen over macarons?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: U.S. Defense Secretary Makes Secret Visit to Afghanistan
description: Lloyd J. Austin III is the first member of President Biden’s cabinet to travel to the country, where he met with the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III landed in Afghanistan’s capital Sunday morning, becoming the first member of President Biden’s cabinet to set foot in the country that is home to America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Clash Between Union Campaigns and Private Property at Supreme Court
description: A California regulation lets labor organizers enter private property to meet with farmworkers. In a case the court will hear Monday, challengers say that amounts to a government taking of property.
content: WASHINGTON — Before dawn on an October morning in 2015, representatives of the United Farm Workers turned up at a strawberry plant nursery in Northern California to meet with workers and urge them to consider unionizing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Sugam
title: After 30 Years, Rutgers Finds Its Way Back to the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Steve Pikiell revived the Rutgers men's basketball program using a trusted blueprint borrowed from his former UConn coach, John Calhoun.
content: Jim Calhoun knows a thing or two about building something out of nothing, and it turns out that Steve Pikiell, now the Rutgers coach, was paying close attention all those years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Go Ahead, Put Off Your Taxes
description: An extra month to file your tax returns, a tense U.S.-China meeting and vaccine passports from Walmart.
content: Good morning and happy spring. Here’s hoping you can enjoy another Sunday spent ignoring your tax returns (or, if you’ve already done them, feeling smug about it). But first, here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Coronavirus, Atlanta, March Madness: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Next from Taylor Mac: A Post-Pandemic Pandemic Play — Set in 1918
description: “Joy and Pandemic” is slated to be performed this fall before an in-person audience at the Magic Theater in San Francisco.
content: What kind of art the coronavirus pandemic will inspire remains an open question. But the playwright and performer Taylor Mac has spent much of the past year of theatrical shutdown creating a work about the last Big One.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Delight In the Seasonal Green of Asparagus
description: Spring starts with “A” for asparagus, one of the most versatile of vegetables. (Apologies to artichokes.)
content: Spring is a new beginning. At the produce stand, spring starts with “A” for asparagus, one of the most versatile of vegetables. Asparagus can be served raw, steamed, boiled, sautéed, roasted, stir-fried, deep-fried, puréed for soup or a dip, and baked in custards, tarts and soufflés.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Reid J. Epstein
title: Assaulting the Truth, Ron Johnson Helps Erode Confidence in Government
description: Pushing false theories on the virus, the vaccine and the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Mr. Johnson, the Republican senator from Wisconsin, has absorbed his party’s transformation under Donald Trump.
content: BROOKFIELD, Wis. — Senator Ron Johnson incited widespread outrage when he said recently that he would have been more afraid of the rioters who rampaged the Capitol on Jan. 6 had they been members of Black Lives Matter and antifa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudine Ko
title: There Are Two Asian-Americas, and One Is Invisible
description: Who will recognize the humanity of the women who help us heal?
content: To get a Chinatown-style massage in New York, you don’t actually have to head down to Canal Street. There are countless spas across the city, obscure storefronts you hear about through word of mouth, places sporting familiar signage: BACK & FOOT RUB. They follow a similar business model: no frills, volume, astonishingly affordable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: $29 Billion Railroad Merger to Connect U.S., Mexico and Canada
description: The deal is an effort by Canadian Pacific and Kansas City Southern to capitalize on an expected increase in the flow of trade as the three countries rebound from the pandemic.
content: Canadian Pacific and Kansas City Southern announced plans on Sunday to combine in a $29 billion deal that would create the first railroad network connecting the United States, Mexico and Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: $325,000 Settlement for Teacher Over Trump References Removed From Yearbook
description: A New Jersey teacher was suspended in 2017 after, she says, the school administration told her to remove a reference to Mr. Trump from a student’s shirt in a photo.
content: For years, Susan Parsons said she was told by administrators to remove “controversial” content from the high school yearbook in Wall Township, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Some U.S. Muslim groups try to spread the word that getting a Covid shot won’t break the Ramadan fast.
description: A Covid task force cites Islamic scholars, and adds that the shot “will not invalidate the fast because it has no nutritional value and it is injected into the muscle.”
content: With Ramadan less than a month away, some Muslim organizations in the United States have begun addressing a critical question: whether the dawn-to-dusk Ramadan fast prohibits Muslims from receiving vaccine injections during daylight hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Robina Asti, Who Made History on the Ground and in the Air, Dies at 99
description: As a transgender veteran in her 90s, she challenged government bureaucracy. She then set out to be recognized as the oldest working flight instructor.
content: Robina Asti, a World War II veteran and mutual-fund executive who inspired a generation of transgender people in the 2010s with her successful fight for her husband’s Social Security benefits, and who just last year became the world’s oldest active flight instructor, died on March 12 in San Diego. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Two New Orleans State Senators Win Runoff Spots for U.S. House Seat
description: Troy Carter and Karen Carter Peterson will meet in an April runoff for the seat vacated by Cedric L. Richmond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerry Mullany
title: U.K. Police Bill Protesters Turn Violent at Bristol Rally
description: A “kill the bill” rally deteriorated into chaos as protesters attacked the police in a southwest Britain city.
content: Violent protests erupted Sunday night in the British city of Bristol over a proposed police and crime bill that would create sweeping new restrictions on protests and grant broad new powers to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cameron Walker
title: Greet Spring With a Visit to a Public Garden
description: These eight gardens, located across the country, welcome visitors with a range of beloved blooms, traditional collections and experiential outdoor spaces.
content: Last year, the pandemic shut the gates of many public gardens just as spring was on its way: According to a survey by the American Public Gardens Association, only about 4 percent of public gardens remained fully open as of March 30, 2020. Once public gardens began to reopen months later, they became places of natural respite for visitors, perhaps even more so than in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: After Tony Hsieh’s Shocking Death, Zappos Looks to Move Forward
description: Kedar Deshpande, who took over as C.E.O. in August, needs to lead the shoe seller out of the pandemic, while maintaining what his predecessor built.
content: It was never going to be easy to succeed Tony Hsieh, the celebrated chief executive of Zappos, who turned a tiny online shoe seller into a $1 billion behemoth through an obsessive focus on corporate culture and happy employees. But Kedar Deshpande took over at a particularly fraught time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Elsa Peretti, Star Designer of Elegant Jewelry, Dies at 80
description: Celebrities wore Ms. Peretti’s creations on the red carpet and in the movies. Some years her merchandise represented 10 percent or more of Tiffany’s sales.
content: Elsa Peretti, the fashion model turned jewelry designer whose elegant, sculptural creations for Tiffany & Company revolutionized tastes in accessories and repositioned sterling silver as a luxury material, died on Thursday night at her home in Sant Martí Vell, a village in Catalonia, Spain. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Stein, Haley Willis, Danielle Miller and Michael S. Schmidt
title: ‘We’ve Lost the Line!’: Radio Traffic Reveals Police Under Siege at Capitol
description: The Times obtained District of Columbia police radio communications and synchronized them with footage from the scene to show in real time how officers tried and failed to stop the attack on the U.S. Capitol.
content: The Times obtained District of Columbia police radio communications and synchronized them with footage from the scene to show in real time how officers tried and failed to stop the attack on the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Defense Secretary Austin Makes Unannounced Visit to Afghanistan
description: Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with reporters on Sunday after meeting with the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani. The defense secretary declined to comment on a withdrawal deadline for U.S. troops tentatively set for May 1.
content: Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with reporters on Sunday after meeting with the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani. The defense secretary declined to comment on a withdrawal deadline for U.S. troops tentatively set for May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Police Break Up Spring Break Crowds in Miami Beach
description: The police fired pepper balls to disperse crowds after an 8 p.m. curfew went into effect on Saturday. Local Miami officials said people had flocked to the city because of its relatively few coronavirus restrictions.
content: The police fired pepper balls to disperse crowds after an 8 p.m. curfew went into effect on Saturday. Local Miami officials said people had flocked to the city because of its relatively few coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Government Is the Solution, Not the Problem’
